predictions: The prime ministers of India and Japan met in Tokyo.

India's new Prime Minister Narendra Modi meets his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe in Tokyo during his first significant foreign visit since his election victory in May to discuss economic and security relations.
Mr. Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to strengthen economic relations with the world's third-largest economy.
Plans for stronger nuclear technological cooperation are at the very top of the agenda.

Karratha police arrest 20-year-old after high-speed motorcycle chase.
A motorcycle was seized after the rider had driven it at 125 km/h in a 70 km/h zone and through bushland to escape from the police in Pilbara.
Traffic police officers in Karratha attempted this morning to stop a blue motorcycle after they observed it leaving a petrol station on Bathdate Road at 125 km/h.
The police report that the driver then ignored the stop signals and continued along Burgess Road before turning into the bushland, where the officers lost sight of him.
The motorcycle, as well as a person matching the description of the rider, were later seen at a house on Walcott Way in Bulgarra.
The Karratha police charge a 20-year-old man with disregarding a stop signal and reckless driving.
He is to appear before the local court in Karratha on September 23.
The motorcycle was seized and confiscated for three months.
George Webster charged over hotel rapes in Naim and Pitlochry.
A man is on trial for the rape of women in two hotels.
George Webster, 28, had the indictment read to him at a hearing at the High Court in Glasgow.
He is accused of having raped a woman on June 7, 2013, at Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire.
The charge is that Webster assaulted her while she was "unconscious, asleep, and unable to signal consent."
Furthermore, Webster is accused of having raped a second woman on May 4, 2014, at the Golf View Hotel in Nairn in the Scottish Highlands.
Judge Lady Rae scheduled the trial date for November 17th at the High Court in Edinburgh.
A return to the very American ideal of labor rights as human rights.
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis have introduced a legislative proposal to establish the organization of labor unions as a civil right.
"As unions die, so too do middle-class jobs," said Ellison, a Democrat from Minnesota and deputy chair of the Progressive Caucus in Congress.
Therefore, I am proudly introducing, together with civil rights icon John Lewis, the Employee Empowerment Act.
This groundbreaking law gives workers the same legal options in cases of discrimination because of union organizing as in other forms of discrimination—and thus stops anti-union forces.

The amendment of the national labor law act, to create an opportunity for workers exposed to discrimination to organize union representation, to sue for justice before a civil court—and to receive compensation or penalties—is a sensible and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative – at least not by American standards..
In fact, the best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and the other sponsors of their bill are proposing is to connect back to a very American idea.

Despite the setbacks that labor unions have faced in recent years—in Wisconsin, Michigan, and other states across the country—Americans once encouraged countries around the world to recognize, expand, and uphold labor rights.
There was a time, which millions of Americans still remember, when this country mentioned democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, and the right of assembly in the same breath.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas MacArthur and his staff encouraged the country to adopt a constitution that would ensure that Hideki Tojo's militarized autocracy would be replaced by democracy.

In full awareness that the workers and their unions played a role in the creation of a new Japan, they used language that explicitly recognized that "the rights of workers to association and collective bargaining and action are guaranteed."

When the United States occupied Germany after the Second World War, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his staff urged the Germans to write a constitution that would ensure Adolf Hitler's fascism would be replaced by a strong democracy.

In recognition of the fact that the workers would have to organize themselves, and should raise their voice in the new nation, the Germans inserted a clause which explicitly stated: "The right to form associations to secure and improve working and economic conditions is guaranteed to every individual and every profession or trade."
Agreements that restrict this right or aim to diminish it are null and void; measures aiming at this are illegal.

When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the International Human Rights Commission, which drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as it was adopted by the United Nations in 1948 as a global agreement, Roosevelt and the other authors included a guarantee that "everyone has the right to form or join trade unions for the protection of his interests."
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labor rights are human rights.

As this country advised other countries on how one could form civil and democratic societies, Americans declared that the right to establish a union—and that this union may then participate in collective bargaining as an equal partner with companies and government agencies—must be protected.

After these rights came under attack in America, it is indeed very wise to recall the American ideal, according to which the working population must have the right to unite and make their voices heard in a free and open society.
"As Pastor Martin Luther King Jr. said fifty years ago:"
History is a great teacher.
Now everyone knows that the labor movement did not limit the nation's strength but increased it.
By raising the living standard of millions of people, labor has miraculously created a market for industry and lifted the entire nation to unimaginable levels of production.
Those who attack the work forget these simple truths, but history preserves them.
History remembers, and so should we.

The formal recognition of labor rights as human rights—and the expansion of the protection of civil rights as a safeguard against discrimination in the creation of employee representative bodies—is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis are renewing the ideals that made America great in the past and fulfilled the promise of democracy.
Judge temporarily stops law that could force all abortion clinics in Louisiana to close.
On Sunday, a U.S. federal judge temporarily halted the implementation of a law in Louisiana that lawyers say would likely have led to the closure of all five of the state's abortion clinics.

This measure, which was signed into law by Bobby Jindal, Governor of Louisiana, in June and is set to take effect on September 1st, would force doctors who perform abortions to obtain admitting privileges at a hospital within a 30-mile radius of their practice.
However, the judge's decision means that doctors can, for the time being, continue to legally perform abortions while they apply for such a right.
"The plaintiffs can continue working in compliance with the law while they seek to obtain these rights," wrote Federal Judge John deGravelles in his ruling.
Within a month, a hearing will be scheduled for the judge to bring about a more permanent decision regarding the law.
Abortion advocates welcomed the decision, the latest in a series of rulings against similar measures, and said that doctors would thus gain more time to obtain hospital admitting privileges.

"Today's decision means that the women in Louisiana escape a devious law that wants to take away their health and their rights," said Nancy Northup, president and chairperson of the Center for Reproductive Rights, which had sued on behalf of three of the state's five clinics to stop the law.
It was not immediately clear whether the judgment also extended to the doctors from the two clinics who had not joined the lawsuit and had also requested admission rights.
Louisiana is one of 11 states that have enacted similar laws, with courts recently declaring such measures in Alabama and Mississippi to be unconstitutional.
Key provisions of a law in Texas that would have forced most of the remaining clinics in the state to close were halted by a federal judge on Friday.

Proponents of abortion and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, as well as the American Medical Association, all agree that doctors' admitting privileges impose unnecessary restrictions.
Abortion opponents counter that the measures serve to protect women's health, although some also welcomed the effects of clinic closures.
Only one doctor who performs abortions in Louisiana has patient admitting privileges, the Center for Reproductive Rights said.
"If all other doctors in the state are forced to stop performing abortions, this doctor would no longer perform the operation out of fear for his safety, the group said."

During their argument against the ruling, representatives of the state of Louisiana said that they would not punish any doctors for performing abortions while their applications for admitting privileges were still pending.
Delayed diagnoses and lack of access to the best treatment options lead to higher death rates from ovarian cancer in rural areas.
Angelina Jolie and her brother James have posted an online video tribute to their mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
For women in the rural areas of Australia, there is a higher risk of dying from ovarian cancer than for women in cities.

Researchers analyzed the medical data of more than 1,100 Australian women who were diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005 and found that only 25 percent were still alive five years after the diagnosis.

The research director Susan Jordan from the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said that for those who lived in rural and remote regions of the state, the mortality risk during the study was 20 percent higher than for those in urban areas.
SMALL STUDY: New drugs could slow lung and ovarian cancer.
The researchers studied the medical care of the women over seven years.
Dr. Jordan said that a woman's age at diagnosis, the type of ovarian cancer, existing preexisting conditions, as well as social and economic status also influenced the chances of survival.
For older women and those whose cancer was already more advanced at the time of diagnosis, the survival rate was the lowest.
For those who lived in rural and remote regions of the state, the mortality risk during the study was 20 percent higher than for those in urban areas.

Although the study did not examine why women living outside the city were more likely to die from ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suspects delayed diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatment centers as possible factors.
"This disease is best treated by gynecologic oncologists, and these are mostly found in larger cities," she said.

Despite the improvements in telemedicine services to somewhat counteract the distances, she proposed as a possible remedy strengthening the service of flown-in doctors, to give specialists the opportunity to provide care to women closer to their homes, as well as treatment programs for people outside their region.

Dr. Jordan said that the study, regardless of geographical status, showed a poor long-term survival rate in women with ovarian cancer and underscored the need for better treatment and prevention strategies.
The study funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer is being published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2013, Elisha Neave, a young 33-year-old mother from the Gold Coast, found out that she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.
Garden centers regret declining numbers of homeowners.

The decline, together with an intensified decrease in the number of homeowners under 35 years old, could lead to garden centers losing tens of thousands of pounds per year when today's young consumers reach the "core age group for garden products," according to a study by the HTA, as reported in the Financial Times.
The report states that renters spend on average 55 percent of the amount that homeowners spend on their garden.

The rise in the number of people living in highly urbanized areas without gardens, the popular practice of paving over front gardens for parking purposes, and the decreasing garden size are further factors that threaten the industry, in which an estimated £5 billion in sales are generated annually.
In the Greater London area, where over a period of six years the percentage of homeowners has fallen from 61% to 43%, the lowest expenditures on garden products per household are reported.
The HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society point out that renting or having small gardens doesn't mean people can't grow plants.
Guy Barter, chief garden advisor for the RHS, said: "Container gardening is, for example, very popular among tenants because they can take their plants with them when moving."
The HTA report identified the period between 1997 and 2005 as the "golden age" of garden retail due to rising numbers of homeowners and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-90s.
He also predicted an improved market situation for this year due to better weather following unfavorable weather conditions in March and April of last year.

In the capital Islamabad, around 1000 demonstrators have stormed the state television broadcaster PTV.
Information Minister Pervaiz Rashid said that soldiers had been able to drive the protesters out of the PTV building again.
The broadcaster suspended operations for around 40 minutes but is now broadcasting again.
At the same time, around 3,000 demonstrators tried to reach the residence of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.

The police used tear gas.
The demonstrators demanded Sharif's resignation, but he refuses.
The country's army, meanwhile, is urging a political solution to the conflict "without wasting time and without resorting to violence."
After a meeting at headquarters on Sunday evening, the military announced: "The army remains committed to its role of ensuring the security of the state."
The military plays an important role in Pakistan and has already staged coups multiple times.
The opposition politician Imran Khan accuses Prime Minister Sharif of having cheated in the parliamentary elections in May of last year.
"The protests escalated over the weekend after Khan and Qadri called on their supporters to advance to Sharif's residence."
In the process, three people had been killed.
Turkey summons U.S. diplomat over espionage report.
The Turkish Foreign Ministry has summoned the most senior U.S. diplomat in the country to provide information about a report on American and British espionage in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bülent said that the chargé d'affaires of the U.S. embassy and Turkish officials had discussed the report on Monday.

The German magazine Der Spiegel as well as the online magazine The Intercept reported that the documents from former U.S. National Security Agency analyst Edward Snowden show that Turkey was a main area of activity for the U.S. and British intelligence services.
According to Turkish news agencies, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan played down the importance of the report and said that all major countries spy on each other.
A previous report that even Germany's most important intelligence agency had Ankara in its sights led to significantly angrier reactions from the Turkish government.

The strike announced for 6 pm to 9 pm affects all transportation companies nationwide, including long-distance, regional, and S-Bahn services.

said the district chairman of the German Train Drivers' Union (GDL), Sven Schmitte, in Düsseldorf.
We are expecting significant outages.

On Friday, the accusers presented evidence of extortion by police officers and employees of the city of Calvià to the office of the prosecutor of Mallorca.
The chief of police of Calvià on the holiday island of Mallorca was arrested following corruption allegations made by businessmen and bar owners in the notorious binge-drinking hotspot Magaluf.

Chief Inspector José Antonio Navarro was taken into custody after allegations of corruption against him by several businessmen from Punta Ballena, the street where most of Magaluf's bars and nightclubs are located.

According to the online daily newspaper Mallorca Diario, the plaintiffs submitted evidence of extortion by police officers and employees of the city of Calvià to the Office of the Prosecutor for Anti-Corruption of Mallorca on Friday.
Two more local police officers were arrested by the Spanish Guardia Civil in connection with the corruption allegations and are being questioned together with Navarro by a judge.
The national Spanish daily newspaper ABC reported that the disgruntled nightclub owners stated that the authorities' nepotism was having serious effects on their businesses.
"It's not about making money anymore; it's about survival," one of the businessmen told the court.
Leave our basis of life out of this.
We have nothing to lose..
Magaluf made international headlines this summer due to a viral YouTube video showing an 18-year-old British tourist performing fellatio on 24 men during a drinking tour.
Since then, the island authorities have tried to stop the disorderly behavior of intoxicated tourists in Magaluf by minimizing the number of participants in the notorious alcohol-fueled pub crawls.
The Playhouse Club, where the fellatio incident took place, was forced to close for a year, while Playhouse and the pub crawl organizer Carnage must jointly pay a fine of €55,000 ($73,000).

The tourist resort of Magaluf, which is especially popular among young British holidaymakers, is also known for numerous alcohol-related accidents, including the trend of "balconing," where people jump from one balcony to another or from a balcony into the hotel pool.
The first spring day with wet and stormy weather conditions is affecting flights from Adelaide Airport.
Spring has given South Australia a wintry surprise, with heavy showers and strong winds that disrupted flights from Adelaide Airport.
In the evening until 9 p.m., an additional 5mm of rain fell on the city, after 6.6mm had already come down during the night before Sunday.
The last precipitation was the result of a series of short, stormy showers, including a downpour that began shortly before 8 p.m. and produced nearly 4 mm of precipitation in about 10 minutes.
After winter had provided an early taste of spring last week, temperatures in the city fell again on Monday to a high of only 15.8°C.
The gusty weather conditions have probably led to the delayed landing of a Virgin Airlines flight from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The airplane was supposed to land shortly after 7:30 p.m., but was hit by a wind shear—a sudden change in wind speed or direction over a short distance—and had to go around.
At that time, wind gusts reached about 50 km/h at ground level at Adelaide Airport.
The flight data showed that the aircraft had to go around even on a second landing approach and finally touched down at around 8:40 pm.
The flight delay subsequently led to the delay of several other flights, including an Emirates flight from Dubai and a Qantas flight from Sydney.
For Adelaide, a maximum temperature of 16°C is forecast on Tuesday, with possible showers.
Matthies says: It's high time for major networking.

In view of the galloping technological progress that threatens to transform our cozy home into high-tech control centers, our columnist Bernd Matthies consoles himself with a very familiar electronic accessory.
As I write this, my eyes fall upon the spiral cord that connects the handset to the telephone, and I think: "Wow, how retro is that?"
"But there's a thought behind it: If it weren't for the cable, all the headphones would be flying around the house ownerless in no time, and that would be even more retro."
"After all, it applies anyway on the ekeltronic (ekeltronic?)."
No, not a typo: In the electronic sector, the rule is that today's world novelty is tomorrow's electronic waste—bought and already obsolete.
"And anyone who, for example, still has a tube television in their living room today is merely indicating that they fundamentally reject television."
Why these considerations?
Because the influx of the IFA at the Radio Tower this week once again makes us aware of our absolute incompetence in matters of electronics.

The layman, who used to master the washing machine and CD player with his eyes closed, nowadays doesn't even grasp the purpose of the devices that are spread out before him with unbelievably conceited expert jargon: "Connected Home, Wearables, Health Care, and Urban Technologies," the press office promises us.
Seriously, what's wrong with you?
What should one talk about with people who obviously voluntarily spread such nonsense?
Basically, for about 20 years now, it's mainly been about us being told that we should damn well network our house.
So that the yogurt reorders itself, so that the smoke detector informs us during our vacation in the Maldives that the study is currently on fire...
"And wouldn't it be wonderful if we could, from the office, set the air conditioning for our imminent arrival...?"
Yes, however, that does require an air conditioner.
But a dream will definitely soon come true: We lift our wristwatch, say to it loudly "Vacuum!"—and at home the robotic vacuum cleaner starts up.
Crazy..

Everything is leading to nothing less than a revolution: "The boundaries between white and brown goods are blurring," whispers an industry insider. You can connect the washing machine to a pair of headphones, the steam cooker sends the weather report, and the smart glasses display how long the pizza in the oven still needs—which is of no use, however, because we're stuck in traffic.
Moreover, as we know from daily experience: When a newfangled device is urgently needed, the battery is guaranteed to be dead.
Which is another reason why the telephone's spiral cable will survive even the next radio exhibitions.
Israeli children return to their schools after the war in Gaza.

Thousands of Israeli children from areas near the Gaza Strip returned to school on Monday, after spending the summer in bomb shelters while rocket and mortar fire rained down on their communities during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas, and the schools in Gaza remained closed as the area recovered from the fighting.
The start of school brought a feeling of joy and anticipation to the rocket-scarred communities in southern Israel, but the signs of the fighting are still fresh.
In the southern city of Ashdod, staff members of the "Pashosh" kindergarten—which had been hit by a rocket—removed shrapnel from the walls and sliding partitions before the students arrived.
"We are a little scared, but excited," said Ronit Bart, a resident of Kibbutz Sa'ad and the English teacher there.
Many children from our area urgently need the return to a routine.
Her 11-year-old daughter Shani Bart said it feels "a bit strange" to suddenly go back to school again.
"Those were difficult times, and we did not go out of the house at all," she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited the kibbutz near the border with Gaza to offer his support.

Until a ceasefire interrupted the war last week, thousands of residents of border communities like Saad stayed in their homes or left to move to safer areas farther away from Gaza to escape the rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, a community near the border with Gaza where a 4-year-old boy was killed by a Palestinian mortar shell, are still hesitant to return.
The Ministry of Education announced that about a dozen families have not yet returned.
Your children have been temporarily placed in other schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a border town with Gaza that has been heavily affected by Palestinian shelling.
He appealed to the children to learn a lot and said, "We will ensure that you acquire knowledge and offer you security."
Israel and Hamas agreed last Tuesday to an indefinite ceasefire.

The ceasefire provided for an immediate end to the fighting; however, important problems remain unresolved, such as Hamas's demand for the lifting of the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of Gaza's air and sea ports.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the handover of the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in the fighting.
A new round of indirect talks is expected to begin in Egypt later this month.
In the war, more than 2,100 Palestinians were killed, three quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children, according to estimates by the Palestinians and the UN.
Israel disputes these statements and estimates that at least half of those killed are combatants but did not present any concrete evidence for this information.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, were killed.
Hamas and other fighters in Gaza fired 4,591 rockets and mortar shells at Israeli cities during the fighting, most of them in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli military carried out more than 5,000 air and other attacks.
Israeli attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of houses in the Gaza Strip, and about 250,000 people sought refuge in more than 100 UN schools that were converted into temporary shelters.
While tens of thousands of people continue to live in shelters and the fighting persists, the educational authorities postponed the start of the school year last week.

"I hope the school is open again soon so that we can continue learning, like the children in the world and the Jewish children," said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy who currently lives in a school in Gaza City.
After the election in Saxony: CDU deputy leader Strobl questions the NPD ban proceedings.

In view of the National Democratic Party's (NPD) loss of votes in Saxony, Thomas Strobl, Deputy Federal Chairman of the CDU, has spoken out in favor of ending the ongoing NPD ban proceedings before the Federal Constitutional Court.
Berlin – According to CDU deputy federal chairman Thomas Strobl, the ongoing ban proceedings against the NPD should come to an end before the Federal Constitutional Court.
"The NPD is performing worse than last time," said Strobl, who is also the CDU state leader in Baden-Württemberg, to the "Leipziger Volkszeitung".
That is a welcome development in the right direction and a development that rather leads me to the conclusion that the NPD should be fought politically and not before the Constitutional Court.
The NPD narrowly failed to clear the five-percent threshold in Sunday's vote.
A first attempt to ban the right-wing extremist party failed in 2003 because the Office for the Protection of the Constitution also had informants within the NPD leadership at that time.
In December 2013, after long preparation, the Bundesrat submitted a new application in Karlsruhe.
The federal government and the Bundestag did not join in..
Harburg: Tents for new refugees
At Neuländer Square, refugees are now being accommodated in tents.
The central initial reception center for refugees in Harburg is bursting at the seams.
Now the interior authorities have had three Red Cross tents set up beside it.
The district politicians were only informed shortly beforehand—they are not very enthusiastic.

"These hasty actions continue to fuel citizens' reservations and give district politicians no opportunity to contribute constructively to the humane accommodation of refugees," says, for example, Britta Herrmann, chairwoman of the Green Party faction in the Harburg district assembly.
Their party demands that the Harburg district administration make currently unused houses available for accommodation.
96 refugees can be accommodated in the three tents.
The reasons for overcrowding in the initial reception facilities are the influx of people seeking help—and the fact that the authorities cannot provide enough places in follow-up facilities.
Many refugees therefore stay longer than the regular three months.
House prices have experienced the strongest winter increase in seven years, a widely-watched index shows.
The RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic Home Value Index for homes in the Australian capital rose by 1.1 percent in August, according to RP Data on Monday.
Due to this increase, the total rise in June, July, and August is at 4.2 percent, the largest increase in the winter months since 2007.
The annual price increase was at 10.9 percent, more than twice as high as the increase in the 12 months up to August 2013, but the increases were not evenly distributed across the country.
The head of research at RP Data, Tim Lawless, reported that Sydney and Melbourne are driving a two-tiered market.
The figures from RP Data show that house prices in Sydney rose by 16.1 percent in the past year, whereas in Melbourne they rose by 11.7 percent.
The following markets are Adelaide, Brisbane, and Darwin, where prices increased on average by five and six percent.
At the other end of the scale is Canberra, which was hit hard by cuts in government spending and where prices rose by only 1.4 percent over the year..
Mr. Lawless went on to say that with the onset of spring, an increase in properties for sale would be observed over the next few months, which would subject the market to "a real test."

"Considering the consistently high rate of auction prices, a generally fast sales rate, and the persistently low interest rate environment, it is likely that home prices will continue to rise over the next three months," he said.

Glandorf retires from the national handball team.
Holger Glandorf will no longer play for the German national handball team.
The 31-year-old from the Bundesliga club SG Flensburg-Handewitt cited health problems above all as the reason for this decision.
The decision didn't come easily to me; it matured over several months.
"It is time for me to listen to the signals of my body and end my career with the national team," announced the 2007 world champion on his Facebook page.
He thus retires from international play with a record of 167 international matches and 576 goals for Germany.

Because the powerful backcourt player for the Champions League winner from Flensburg wants to continue hunting for goals for a few more years, he is now no longer available to the new national coach Dagur Sigurdsson.
Glandorf had a "long and good conversation" with the Icelander, who will announce his squad for the international matches against Switzerland on Tuesday.
His ideas and approaches have inspired me just as much as they will inspire my long-time teammates and my successors.
"But I also want to remain healthy and available for my club in the coming years; for that, longer recovery periods are necessary, which the current double burden does not allow."
The left-hander had even had to fear the end of his career in 2012 after a heel infection.
Due to Achilles tendon problems, he had himself treated by team doctors of the German Handball Federation (DHB) with a cortisone injection, which later triggered a severe inflammation.
An emergency surgery and two more procedures followed.
Then, Glandorf had announced a lawsuit against the team doctor; the dispute ended with a settlement.
12 years of professional and 11 years of national team career do not pass by any body without leaving a trace.
I have some health issues that I can no longer ignore.
After the three infection-related foot surgeries, which took place in quick succession in 2012, I never really got my blood pressure under control.
"In addition, there are some other complaints caused by wear and tear."
"Already at the beginning of the year I noticed that although I can control my mind, I cannot deceive my body," Glandorf explained in an interview with the magazine "Handball Time".
He would only be available for a comeback in an absolute emergency.
"If all else fails, I am always ready to talk," explained the father of two to the trade magazine.
However, I can count on one hand the years I have left to play handball.
I must also say that I have also become quite humble regarding my health after my long hospital stay in 2012.
After my career, I would at least like to be able to walk somewhat straight.
In addition to the 2007 World Championship title and winning the Champions League in 2014, he won the EHF Cup in 2008 (with HSG Nordhorn) and in 2010 (with TBV Lemgo).
In 2012, he also secured the European Cup Winners' Cup with Flensburg.
German economy shrank by 0.2 percent in the spring.
The crises around the globe have slowed the German economy in the second quarter.
The gross domestic product fell by 0.2 percent from April to the end of June 2014 compared to the previous quarter.
The Federal Statistical Office announced this, thereby confirming preliminary calculations.
Consumption alone boosted the economy in the spring, while investments decreased.
"Foreign trade also slowed down the economy."
Thanks to the strong start to the year, the first half overall saw a GDP increase of 0.8 percent compared to the second half of 2013.
Horstmar was the starting point and the destination of the "Münsterland-Mooiste," which on Sunday passed through the Burgmann town for the first time.
The Burgmann town of Horstmar experienced an invasion of Dutch "Fietzenfahrer" on Sunday.
The largest cycling association in the Netherlands, NTFU, organized the so-called "Münsterlande-Mooiste".
This is the largest cycling tour across the Münsterland, the cyclist's paradise near the Netherlands.
Over 1,000 participants expressed their gratitude to Jos ter Huerne for organizing this tour through the Münsterland by registering.
Advertised in various professional journals, this tour was offered to interested parties.
We come from Den Helder and have traveled overnight to participate in this tour.
"We would also like to get to know the Münsterland more closely in this way," the cyclists were pleased about the route through the districts of Steinfurt, Borken, and Coesfeld.
After registering at the clubhouse of the Marksmen's Brotherhood Sta...
Katharina went on a little "Peace Ride" through the city over the Wall, where the start also took place.
The route, which was advertised for three different categories, continued toward Herrenholz, over the Schöppinger Mountain toward Coesfeld, and via Havixbeck and Billerbeck back to Horstmar.

On routes of 95 kilometers with 1,175 meters of elevation gain, 120 kilometers with 1,475 meters of elevation gain, and 145 kilometers with 1,775 meters of elevation gain, the cyclists proved their good fitness.
They were fed en route in Havixbeck and Billerbeck.
Main organizer Jos ter Huerne and deputy mayor Heinz Lölfing were very pleased with the success of this cycling event.
We are satisfied, and it was a pleasant experience for all involved.
"The organization went smoothly and there were no negative incidents," said Heinz Lölfing, drawing a positive conclusion about this event.
Unfortunately, not as many participants came as the organizer had hoped, which was probably due to the bad weather forecasts and the morning rain.

"We will see each other again in 2015, hopefully with nice weather on August 30th or during another weekend," but the cyclists nevertheless promised to return to Münsterland again, and the organizers are planning a new edition.
Konstantin Wecker's brutally honest memoirs.
What Konstantin Wecker—songwriter, pacifist, political activist, ex-prisoner—has put on paper over 287 pages in "Monk and Warrior" is actually more of a philosophical testament than a biography.
Instead of chronologically, the Munich native born on June 1, 1947, has written down his memoirs more as a series of thought fragments, each chapter introduced by a fitting song lyric.
"And he is brutally honest about it: From masturbation as a high school student to shoplifting and drug use, he leaves out no human weakness."
Also, to show how he himself has learned tolerance in dealing with his fellow human beings.

Abstract, yet all the more important concepts also take up a lot of space: love, soul, ego, being in the now, spirituality—all of which he tries to get to the bottom of, in a very philosophical but also very personal way.

And he also explains his pacifism, his social criticism, his political engagement—and also how not only music shaped him (the opera lover became a soul and rock musician), but also his time in prison.
The latter has also brought the bon vivant Konstantin Wecker closer to the ascetic monk, who arises "through subtraction," as he says, "by leaving out all unnecessary things."
Amid all the high-minded views, there are also brief grounding anecdotes: for example, about brawls in a bar frequented by GIs, or a madcap car ride during which he aimed straight at a tree.
Even there, he is ruthlessly honest.
Lenny Henry: My father never hugged me.
Has never said "I love you".
Henry was one of seven children of a family of Jamaican immigrants in Dudley in the Midlands in 1958.
His father, who died when Henry was 19, worked in a factory, and their relationship was limited.
Henry is rehearsing for a comedy, "Rudy's Rare Records," which is partly based on an imaginary conversation with his father and originated from the series on Radio 4.
The soundtrack is a mixture of reggae and rap, with lively melodies.
But Henry had to work through some difficult childhood moments.
He attended "many" therapy sessions after the death of his mother, and Henry is reflective about his relationship with his father.
It was hard to know him.
One never saw his face, only heard his voice: "Stop making that noise..."
Leave your sister alone.
Move!
I want to watch cricket..
My older brothers Seymour and Hilton—who were already adults when I was a child—went with him to the pub and talked about things like the shape of the beer glass or the beauty of a cricket stroke.
I never had such a conversation with him.
For a large part of my life, he was this serious guy in the corner who read the newspaper.
Recently, Henry opened a foundry in Dudley, and although the conditions are better than in his father's time, he nevertheless gained an insight into how life might have been for him.
It is now somewhat brighter, but they are dark, smoky, deep Stygian labyrinths with jets of flame and smoke and lots of soot.
My father used to just lie down in the tub, and then you could gradually hear him start singing, because he could wash the foundry off himself.
As I was walking around there, I realized that he had been doing that for years to put food on the table, and my respect for him grew.
Nevertheless, Henry grew up as a child without expressions of love from his parents.
My father never hugged me; he never said "I love you."
Only when my mother became unwell towards the end of her life did we begin to say, "I love you, I love you, I love you."
Through his own daughter Billie, with Dawn French, he was able to share the love he had missed as a child.
Could you please stop with the "I love you"?
Just stop hugging me!
Dad, I am 22!
with Dawn French..
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She is a great mother.
He is still friends with French, whom he was married to for 25 years.
Dawn is a good person.
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She is a great mother.
Henry's own mother was a diabetic.
That contributed to her death.
So when I became very, very overweight and showed symptoms of diabetes, my doctor said, "You have to be radical.."
So I went through with this fitness thing and also had to go on a drastic diet to reverse the symptoms.
It is very hard..
And it is exhausting..
Nobody likes to eat carrots..
Henry's career change perhaps shows itself in his elegant, close-cropped beard.
Since he was praised by the critics for his Othello, he has been monopolized by the theater.
"The Comedy of Errors" followed, and then "Fences" by August Wilson.
This is a different experience than the sitcoms and comedies that have filled his busy working life.
He started at just 16 years old when he worked in a factory.
A DJ discovered him on stage when he was imitating people and wrote to New Faces about him.
"His television career began in the mid-seventies. 'I was, for quite a long time, the only Black impersonator/comedian on television.'"
He learned on the job.

Not only did I have to grow up in the public eye, but from 1975 to 1985 I also had to learn how I could become an efficient joke-telling machine while being a star on television, and that was really difficult.
Lenny in 1975 on New Faces.

Because his manager owned the stage rights to the Black and White Minstrel Show, a light entertainment program in which people "painted themselves black," Henry performed his comedy there for over five years.
That was very unpleasant for my family.
"I somehow wish that it had never happened, but I don't regret that I did it."
It was a strange, unpleasant position for me, but I collaborated on huge projects and learned how to deal with a large audience.
But this 'years-long award-winning light-hearted pillar of British television' was also a 'grotesque parody of black people.'
By introducing characters that both mocked and celebrated British Black culture, Henry worked in an alternative comedy circuit in the eighties.
The first series of The Lenny Henry Show was broadcast in 1984, and in the nineties he was known, among other things, as the head chef Gareth Blacklock in the sitcom Chef!

Advertising, documentaries, TV series, and film roles shaped his next decade, but after his BBC series LennyHenry.tv in 2008, he thought to himself: "What are you going to do next, Len, because it all feels like you're just killing time or treading water a bit."
After that came a documentary series for Radio 4 titled "What's So Great About...?".
The first episode revolved around Shakespeare.
"I was downright allergic to Shakespeare."

So I was very afraid of it.
Everyone we interviewed for the show—Peter Hall, Trevor Nunn, Adrian Lester, Judi Dench—said, "You should try it..."
Don't badmouth it if you don't know what you're talking about.
Take a few of the words into your mouth, and then you will understand why we all love Shakespeare so much.
Henry performed 20 lines from Othello's last speech for the documentary film, and he was thrilled.
I had the feeling that I could do it.

"That's what it's about, it's a serious matter, take it seriously, learn your text, do a bit of research..."

And it was a success.
"They seemed to be expecting a car accident, and that just didn't happen."
And soon he appeared in The Comedy of Errors.
Suddenly I was in the National Theatre and I could hardly believe it.
"There was a moment when I thought, "Oh, you have changed.""
There was a technical error, and Henry instinctively felt that he had to entertain the audience.

Instead, the stage manager announced that the performance would continue as soon as the problem was solved.
I went off the stage and something inside me said, "Oh, thank God."
I am not responsible for that.
I can leave that to someone else.
"You are acting in a play, so stay in your role."
Henry in Fences at the Duchess Theatre

Panic is very good, it strengthens the tendons.

He says this, of course, with a THUNDERING voice..
So I stand by it.
I really love that..
I love being in a rehearsal room.

I have decided not to do stand-up comedy because I think that this kind of instant gratification from a room full of strangers is somehow dangerous.
If you keep searching for that endlessly, you'll run into a wall with it.

Houthi rebels block streets in Yemen's capital.
In the conflict between Shiite Houthi rebels and the Yemeni government, the Houthis have called for civil disobedience in the capital Sanaa.
"Houthi supporters occupied central streets in Sana'a on Monday, said a spokesman for the Houthi party 'Ansar Allah'."
Access to the parliament has also reportedly been blocked.
Yemeni media report traffic chaos in the capital.
According to the online edition of the newspaper "Yemen Post," Houthi leader Abdulmalik al-Houthi had called for the measures on Sunday evening.
According to the newspaper, Huthi threatened with a further escalation of the conflict should his demands not be met.
The Shiite Houthis are fighting for more independence from Sunni-ruled Yemen and are demanding the resignation of the government.
The Houthi tribe has been besieging the Yemeni capital for almost two weeks.
Approximately 30,000 rebels have set up protest camps along the main access routes to Sanaa.
In the surrounding area, there are repeated bloody battles with the Yemeni army.
Kenya registers civil servants to curb 'ghost workers'.
Kenya has begun biometrically registering all civil servants to remove "ghost workers" from the government's payrolls.
Employees who do not register within the next two weeks would no longer be paid, stated a government announcement.
The government suspects that thousands of people continue to receive salary payments even after they have left the public service.
President Uhuru Kenyatta promised at his inauguration in 2013 to fight corruption in the public service.

During an audit at the beginning of this year, it was determined that at least $1 million (£700,000) per month was being lost in payments to "ghost employees" and through other abusive financial practices.
The government suspects that salaries continue to be paid into accounts after a person has died or leaves public service, reports Wanyama Chebusiri for the BBC from the capital Nairobi.
A government message stated that all officials must now appear at identification centers within the next two weeks to ensure that their data is recorded through biometric registrations.
"All who failed to do this, unless they had a credible excuse, would be removed from the payroll, the message continued."

"Through this approach, a significant contribution is made to the streamlining of the public service by determining the actual number of civil servants and cleaning up the payroll at both levels of government—thus eliminating the 'ghost employees'," said Anne Waiguru, the Cabinet Secretary in the Ministry of Devolution and Planning.
The scandal surrounding art consultant Helge Achenbach will be heard in court for the first time on November 11.

Five heirs of Berthold Albrecht, son of Aldi founder Theo Albrecht, are demanding €19.4 million in damages from Achenbach and two of his companies, which are in insolvency proceedings, in a civil lawsuit at the Düsseldorf Regional Court.
"A court spokeswoman announced this on Monday."
In the complaint, it is stated that Achenbach committed fraud in the purchase of artworks and vintage cars and charged Berthold Albrecht purchase prices higher than those actually paid.
As a result, the agreed commission is said to have turned out higher as well.
Achenbach is said to have purchased valuables worth 121 million euros for Albrecht.
Children need roots and wings.
He worked in education for 44 years, 23 of which as a principal.
From that time, Manfred Richter knows many established residents of Petershausen and Kollbach from their time as students.
His methods were sometimes unconventional, but always driven by his striving to see the person within the student.
The Schneekoppe is the most famous mountain of the Giant Mountains.
Manfred Richter loves the painting featuring a scene from his homeland.
Richter was born in 1930 in Trautenau, North Bohemia, today Trutnov.
Already at the age of 14, after four years of secondary school, he became interested in the teaching profession.
One year later, the Sudeten Germans were dispossessed.
Within half an hour, the family had to leave their house.
After some months in a camp, in 1946 we went to Bavaria—in a freight wagon.
So Richter ended up in Senkendorf in Upper Franconia.
The teacher education took place in Bamberg.

To do this, Manfred Richter had to walk ten kilometers to the nearest train station six times a week, take the train to Bamberg, walk three kilometers across the entire city to school there, and back in the evenings.
After two months, Manfred Richter got a place to sleep in a Red Cross home in Bamberg—together with up to 15 fellow students in a dormitory.
In 1951 he took the first, and in 1954, after three years as a teaching trainee, the second state examination.
Since Upper Franconia had no vacant teaching position for him, he applied to Upper Bavaria and arrived at the school in Kollbach on November 1, 1954.
The "Fräuleinzimmer" was his first "official residence" in the schoolhouse.
In 1958, he moved into a three-room official residence in the newly built teachers' house next to the school.
Manfred Richter bought this house in 1980, after the school in Kollbach had been closed down in 1968.
Up until then, there were three classes in Kollbach within the Petershausen-Kollbach school association, and five in Petershausen.
Starting from the 1968/69 school year, these were consolidated in Petershausen in the present town hall.
When the Indersdorf school association was founded, only the elementary school remained in the town.
To avoid a demotion at the now smaller school, the then-principal Georg Sigl transferred to Karlsfeld—and Manfred Richter became his successor.
However, Petershausen grew, and so starting in September 1982, the children and their teachers could move into the current building, which was expanded in 1997 after Richter's retirement.

Manfred Richter praises the straightforward generosity of the then-mayor Ludwig Götz, who had an additional workshop and, during the 1997 expansion, basement rooms built at municipal expense, although this was not eligible for subsidies according to the guidelines for school buildings.
"Mayor Götz was very supportive of schools," Richter recalled gratefully.

In his entire career, Manfred Richter never forgot the speech of a government representative who had responded to a lecture by a school inspector on law and justice: "One must never forget love." Manfred Richter put into practice what he had heard there as a young teacher.
"One must give children two things: roots and wings," says the 84-year-old.
And he had to find out: "That doesn't always work." Whether he means only his students there, or equally his own six children, is not entirely clear.
In any case, Richter's actions were sometimes unconventional.
"When students fought, they did not receive any punishment assignments from him, nor were they sentenced to detention."
At the municipality's expense, the judge had two pairs of boxing gloves purchased and had the two opponents face off against each other, even if someone might get a black eye in the process.
For the benefit of the school, Richter, as principal, maintained a good relationship with the then mayor Ludwig Götz (CSU).
This prompted the independent judge, after his retirement, to at least run in 1996 as the last candidate on the CSU list for the municipal council.
However, Richter was preselected for sixth place and joined the CSU.
180 kilometers in three days.
HR4 Bike Tour: 700 cyclists make stopovers in the spa park of Bad Salzhausen and in Schotten.
When cyclists on their tour stop in Bad Salzhausen or Schotten, that in itself is nothing special.

On Friday, however, it was the sheer number of people taking a break that made an impression: The 700 participants of the hr4 bike tour, along with their support entourage, enjoyed a pause in the lower spa park of Bad Salzhausen and later a party under the open sky in the Alteburg Park of Schotten.
Under the motto "Cycling and celebrating on newly discovered paths between Nidda and Kinzig," the participants met on Thursday in Bad Vilbel and experienced a concert by Van Baker & Band there.
On Friday, things got serious: The cyclists took on the first stage, the 60 kilometers via Florstadt to Bad Salzhausen and further to Schotten.

In Bad Salzhausen, the athletes were welcomed by Mayor Hans-Peter Seum, who had started along with them by bicycle from Bad Vilbel, and by the head of Bad Salzhausen's municipal enterprise, Petra Schwing-Döring.

For the refreshment of body and mind, all sorts of good things had been prepared: The country women from Ranstadt and Nieder-Mockstadt had baked 85 trays of apple, plum, streusel, and cheesecake, which tasted wonderful to the hardworking cyclists.
"Only country women can bake such cakes," praised a participant from Aulendiebach as he ordered another little piece.
At the drink stand of the sports club Geiß-Nidda, cold refreshments could be purchased.
The "Duo Bravo" entertained the visitors with well-known melodies from operettas and musicals and received enthusiastic applause.
The beautiful ambiance of the park was relaxing.
A gentleman was also enjoying a head massage from his partner: "He deserves it, after all, he already reattached slipped-off bicycle chains today."

Meanwhile, the mayor and the operations manager still had to work: They were interviewed by reporter Rainer Janke at the fountain in front of the Trinkkurhaus and took the opportunity to promote Bad Salzhausen on the radio.
Even promotion manager Tobias Hagen, who has been involved as tour leader since the first hr4 bike tour in 2004, could only take a short breather, as he had plenty to do with the on-site technology.

His pickup truck, in which he, using three telephones and a radio, communicated with his staff and the 15-member motorcycle squad of the Hesse police, wrote Facebook posts, and produced reports, also needed a check.
"The majority of participants come from the Rhine-Main area," he said, "but cyclists have also come from Gießen or Fulda, from Lauterbach or the Taunus, and even from numerous cities in Westphalia."
The number of participants depends a bit on the available accommodation capacities.
In Category I, the participants are accommodated in hotels; in Category II, in communal accommodations.
The cyclists had a good impression of the spa town when they set off again after one and a half hours: "Bye!"
"It was nice in Bad Salzhausen!" they waved goodbye.
After arriving in Schotten, the group was allowed to take a short break.
But in the evening, the cyclists were challenged in the idyllic Alteburg Park.

Under the direction of the Schotten Society for Tourism and City Marketing (GTS), the park had acquired a beautiful festive atmosphere, and naturally, they had prepared delicacies such as Flammkuchen with well-chilled Federweißer.
Mayor Susanne Schaab, GTS Managing Director Markus Hoßfeld, and MSC Chairman Wolfgang Wagner-Sachs, in his capacity as a board member of ADAC Hessen-Thuringia, welcomed the visitors.
The three were visibly delighted about the "much activity in Schotten".
DJ Tobias Hagen then opened the dance floor.
Despite the athletic activity on the bicycle, the opportunity for vigorous movement under the open sky was eagerly seized.
More and more citizens mingled among the guests; they were as delighted by the good atmosphere as the large crowd of cyclists.
On the second day, the cyclists' itinerary included the stops at Birstein, Wächtersbach, and Bad Orb—including a concert with the Trenkwalder.
Yesterday, after 180 kilometers of cycling, the athletes arrived back in Bad Vilbel.
Dozens of Turkish police officers arrested for "conspiracy" against the government.
A total of 33 police officers were arrested in Turkey on suspicion of "conspiracy against the government," local media agencies report.
The police authorities gave no immediate comment.
Among the arrested are 14 high-ranking police officers, reports Hürriyet Daily News.
Some of them were involved in the corruption investigations against government officials, including four government ministers last December.
In July, a number of Turkish police officers were arrested because they had allegedly formed an organized criminal association and had tapped telephone numbers.

The Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan (who was then Prime Minister) described their actions as part of the activities led by the Islamist cleric Fethullah Gülen against him and other people in positions of power.
Not all children in Ukraine are returning to school.
Schools almost everywhere in Ukraine opened on Monday (September 1) after the summer holidays.
This day is traditionally an important day for families, and like thousands of other Ukrainian parents, Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk took his daughter to school.
There, he informed the waiting journalists that not all schools had reopened, but that he was nevertheless determined to defend the country for future generations.
The September celebrations were not held in every school.
The sky is not peaceful everywhere over Ukraine.
We must fight for a peaceful sky.
The entire Ukraine, a vast united Ukrainian people's front, must fight for a peaceful sky.
Aleksan Pastukhow, principal of the school in Slavyansk that Yatsenyuk's daughter attends, spoke in Russian.
We hope that peace will finally prevail here again and that the children will receive an education that will be useful to them in their future lives.
The first day of the new school year is traditionally celebrated, with the children wearing embroidered shirts, holding balloons in their hands, and giving flowers to their teachers.
With Rona Fairhead, the BBC may have found the great director it needs.
She arrives with a proud trail of fame from the banking world, media management, and the inner circle of the Tory Party.
"And she has her own frontline experience.."
Her career began at the global management consulting firm Bain & Co., after which she moved to Morgan Stanley, Bombadier, ICI, and the media world of Pearson.
She was chairwoman of the Financial Times for seven years and resigned when the top position at the parent company Pearson went to a younger male colleague.
Her severance pay allegedly amounted to almost £1 million.
Her political ranking is also solid.
She was recommended to David Cameron by Lord Browne, the former chairman of BP, when he was seeking more private sector expertise in Whitehall: she became an advisor to the cabinet.
Her husband is a former Tory council member.
As early as May, I described the chairman's role as a poisoned chalice.
Not only does the BBC stand as a huge and complex entity at the heart of public life, but there is also an internal paradox in its structure.
Trust works in two directions: inward towards the top ranks of the BBC's own management hierarchy, but also outward as a voice of public concern and unrest when things go wrong.
That leads to an almost untenable duopoly, which calls for a complete comprehensive reform.
But which newly arriving chairman would risk stepping up, attacking everything, and dismantling an institution as complex as a Chinese dynasty, while perhaps jeopardizing his own job in the process.
It is a difficult task..
"And as if that weren't already enough, many are also interested in seeing the BBC downsized—power, money, and status have taken over."
While the competition is drawing closer and new technologies threaten old, comfortable certainties, the upcoming negotiation of license fees for the BBC is fraught with particular dangers.
For the modest sum of £145.50 per year, the British public buys into what is surely the largest media company in the world.
The BBC tells a good story: it says that it reaches 96 percent of all households and costs each of them only 40 pence per day.
And apparently, the BBC is climbing back up the popularity scale: 53 percent support it today, compared to 31 percent ten years ago.
The viewing and usage habits for the BBC have changed: Nowadays, I get news headlines on my mobile phone and watch missed programs later on my iPlayer.
But it remains a very beloved and respected institution.
She needs an impressive chairman—I hope she has found him.
Perry from Texas says that the derogatory tweet was not authorized.

A tweet from the official user account of the Republican Governor of Texas, Rick Perry, on Sunday included a disparaging remark about the Democratic district attorney who is at the center of a criminal indictment against him for abuse of power.
The tweet was later deleted and replaced by another from Perry's user account, which denied the previous one.
A tweet was just sent from my account that I did not authorize.
"I do not approve of the tweet and have deleted it," said the later message.
Perry's representatives did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Although the tweets originated from Perry's official user account, it was not clear who actually operates the feed.
In the earlier tweet, an unflattering image of the district attorney of Travis County, Rosemary Lehmberg, was drawn, who was convicted of drunk driving in April 2013.

Perry vetoed financial funding for her office when she refused to resign, which led to an indictment against Perry—who could possibly be a presidential candidate in 2016—before a grand jury in Austin this month.
The text of the tweet reads: "I don't always drive drunk with three times the legal alcohol limit... but when I do, I indict Governor Perry if he blabs about it."
I am the drunkest Democrat in Texas.
Lehmberg's office was not entrusted with overseeing the grand jury investigation against Perry.
This was led by Michael McCrum, a special prosecutor from San Antonio who was selected by a Republican judge.
Perry pleads not guilty and called the indictment a political trick.

His top-notch team of attorneys filed a motion with the judge overseeing the case to dismiss the indictment, arguing that the law under which proceedings are being brought against the longest-serving governor in the history of the state of Texas is unconstitutionally vague.
Perry halted $7.5 million of state funds to the state's Public Integrity Unit—which is based in Travis County and investigates cases of state corruption in Texas—when Lehmberg refused to resign.
This veto prompted a public complaint from a left-leaning watchdog group.
Perry's official user account is frequently updated – and sometimes becomes famous.

After finishing fifth in the Iowa caucuses during his 2012 presidential campaign, Perry addressed speculation that he would quit by posting a tweet of a photo of himself jogging near a lake, with the words "South Carolina, here we come!"
Berkeley declares housing market 'normal' again.
One of London's most prominent building contractors pointed out that the housing market in the southeast of England has "returned" to normal levels.

Owner-occupied homes in the capital were highly sought after and the subject of enormous price increases, which prompted the Bank of England, due to widespread fears of a credit bubble, to impose caps on mortgage loans in June.

Tony Pidgley, founder and chairman of the high-end construction company Berkeley, said on Monday: "Since the beginning of the current financial year, the market has returned to normal transaction levels since the peak in 2013," and added that this offers a "stable operating environment."
The real estate market in London was well-positioned during the downturn, as foreign buyers flocked to the capital.
According to information from the land registry office, prices in the city area have leaped by 18.5 percent in the past year alone, far more than the average increase in England and Wales overall.
The average selling prices of Berkeley's private, affordable, and student offerings rose by approximately one-fifth in the past year and were around £423,000 at the end of April.

However, a stronger pound has made property ownership in London less attractive for foreign buyers in recent months—some of them have also been deterred by the introduction of new property taxes and political rhetoric about a possible "mansion tax" ahead of the general elections next May.

The London estate agent Foxtons warned last week that the mortgage market report for April, in which stricter lending regulations were introduced, would also lead to lower market growth in the second half of the year, both in property sales and prices.
New data from the Bank of England on Monday show a decline in mortgage approvals in July, which also indicates that the property market is cooling down.

Hamptons International, another real estate agency, revised its forecast for the increase in property prices in London for 2015 downward to 3 percent, based on an already weakening house price sentiment.
According to the real estate agent WA Ellis, the transaction volume in London's most expensive areas like Chelsea, Mayfair, and Kensington has now been decreasing by a quarter year after year.
Nevertheless, the desire for home ownership in the capital is a blessing for Berkeley, as the amounts due from forward sales total more than £2.2 billion.
Mr Pidgley added: "Demand for the right, well-designed product in the best locations has remained stable, and as a result, forward sales have also remained stable."
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 new homes in the year up to the end of April—almost a third more than at the peak in 2007 before the crisis.
Annual pre-tax profit increased by 40 percent year-on-year to £280 million, while revenue rose by 18 percent to £1.6 billion.
In a statement on Monday before the company's annual general meeting, Mr. Pidgley said that the revenues for Berkeley in the current year are expected to meet current market expectations.
The analysts unanimously estimate the annual pre-tax profit at £450 million.
Berkeley shares remained steady at £23.96 in afternoon trading in London.
Nude photos of Jennifer Lawrence published on the internet by hackers.
Jennifer Lawrence's appearance at the 85th Academy Awards ceremony.
Nude photos of Oscar-winning actress Jennifer Lawrence were published online by a hacker who claimed to have a "master list" of pictures of another 100 starlets.
A representative of the star from "The Hunger Games" confirmed that the photos of Lawrence were genuine and pressed charges against the hacker for "egregious violation of privacy."
The authorities have been notified and will prosecute all those who repost the stolen photos of Jennifer Lawrence.

"The photos, which were originally posted on the photo-sharing site 4chan, were allegedly obtained through a vulnerability in Apple's iCloud online storage system. The alleged 'master list' of hacking victims includes the names of dozens of female stars, including Rihanna, Kim Kardashian, Mary Elizabeth Winstead, and Mary-Kate Olsen, BuzzFeed reported."
"It is not certain how many of the pictures are real, although Winstead, star of 'Scott Pilgrim vs. the World', also condemned the hack on Twitter."

For several years, no one had lived in the house.

The pipes were leaky, there were still spiders in the bathrooms, slugs had left their trails on all the windows and believed that everything belonged to them, and the garden was overgrown with weeds that looked like giant cabbages.
It was like the house from a children's fairy tale, both threatening and enticing, a garden full of secrets.

Kevern had been sitting with Ailinn, holding hands on the broken deck chairs in the tall grass, enjoying an unusually warm spring afternoon. Both had absent-mindedly plugged into the service console that supplied the country with soothing music and calming news, when the sight of her crossed brown legs reminded him of an old song by a long-forgotten Black entertainer, whom his father used to like listening to at home behind closed shutters.
Your feet are too big.
Due to their inherent aggressiveness, songs of this kind were no longer played on the console.
Not forbidden - Nothing was truly forbidden - just not played..
It was successfully obsoleted, just like the word "to obsolete."

Ailinn did not understand that.
"That was a well-known song by a jazz pianist named Fats Waller," he explained to her, automatically putting two fingers to his lips.
That was what his father had always done to stop the letter J before it came out of his mouth.

Once again, no laws or constraints applied.
A conformist society meant that every element of this society gratefully agreed to the principle of group endowment—grateful like those spared by fate.

Those from the Gulf states and the Levant, whose grandparents had not quickly left the country when WHAT HAD HAPPENED, WHEN IT HAD HAPPENED happened—out of fear of being accused of stoking the fires, even out of fear that the flames would consume them next—had opened labneh and shisha pipe restaurants, kept a low profile, and became depressed by the inactivity.
From each according to his abilities.
Because she had only heard ballads, Ailinn found it difficult to understand how the insulting words that Kevern had just sung to her could ever have been set to music.

My father never insulted anyone, but he loved this song.
He talked too much, but the neglected garden gave him the deceptive feeling of security.

I'm a little perverse about that.

When he tried to be funny, he often got himself into trouble because, like his father, he did not possess the soothing charm one needed to tame the inherent cruelty in jokes.

The same confused men, with even thicker skin and more sullen after WHAT HAD HAPPENED than their ancestors had been as smugglers and wreckers, went from pub to pub, always ready to raise a hand against a woman who refused them or laughed at them.

A man turned away from her, his back bent, ashamed, defeated, without fighting spirit—why was that a sight she seemed to know well, when she couldn't recall a single time before today when she had ever seen something like that?

Lesotho military member says that no coup is planned; Prime Minister remains in South Africa.

Official representatives of the military in Lesotho denied having planned a coup to overthrow the government and said that they were taking action against police officers who are accused of arming political fanatics.
Prime Minister Thomas Thabane fled the country and announced that the country's army had surrounded his official residence and occupied government buildings in the capital Maseru.
The Prime Minister brought his family into neighboring South Africa after he had reported assassination threats.
Military spokesman Major Ntlele Ntoi said that there is de facto no coup d'état, but that the military is reacting to the threat from "political fanatics" whose arming by the police was imminent.

"What happened this morning was that the staff of the Lesotho Defense Forces acted after they had received several intelligence reports that within the police some elements were operating who actually wanted to arm some of the political, party-affiliated young fanatics who were on the verge of causing devastating damage," he told Voice of America.
The South African government spokesperson Clayson Monyela said that the military action gave the impression of a coup.
"Even though no one has claimed to have seized the government by force, all reports agree that the activities of Lesotho's defense forces so far show signs of a coup," he said.
Spokespersons for the Lesotho military reported on Sunday that the soldiers were withdrawing to their barracks and that the situation in the capital was calm.
In the meantime, Deputy Prime Minister Mothetjoa Metsing takes over leadership of the government during Thabane's absence.
Thabane stated that he believes he has become a target because of his attempt to combat corruption in the country.
In Lesotho, there have been great tensions since June after Thabane suspended parliamentary sessions due to disputes within his unity government.
He said his actions had not undermined the government, despite allegations to the contrary.
Production in the Eurozone at a 13-month low.
Production growth in the Eurozone slowed in August to the lowest point in the last 13 months, according to a closely watched study with...
The final Markit Purchasing Managers' Index for manufacturing (PMI) fell in August to 50.7, after a level of 51.8 in July.
A reading over 50 indicates an expansion.
New orders declined, and factories experienced slumps at a time of rising tensions between the EU and Russia over Ukraine.
The figures arrive before the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting on Thursday.
The markets expect a clear plan from the bank for dealing with a sluggish recovery in the Eurozone, as well as for the looming deflation given an inflation rate of only 0.3%.

There is speculation that the head of the ECB, Mario Draghi, might provide further details this week on whether he is considering quantitative easing for the Eurozone, similar to those implemented by the UK and the USA during the financial crisis.

"Although even small growth is better than no growth at all, the dampening effects of increasing economic and geopolitical uncertainties have become more apparent for manufacturers," said Rob Dobson, senior economist at Markit.
The manufacturing PMI for Germany, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to its lowest level in 11 months at 51.4.
Meanwhile, in the bloc's second-largest economy, France, the PMI fell to 46.9.
France remains a problem child, as does Italy's descent from solid expansion to stagnation.
"Indications that growth incentives within the key industry mechanism in Germany, as well as in Spain and the Netherlands, are no longer taking hold are also not reassuring," said Mr. Dobson.
The decline in industry is likely to fuel the fire of analysts who are expecting further monetary or fiscal incentives.
A positive piece of news came from the Republic of Ireland, where the PMI rose to 57.3, the highest level since the end of 1999.

Howard Archer, chief economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "The best that can be said about the Eurozone manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index for August is that, according to it, the sector continues to grow."

He added: "Producers in the Eurozone are obviously finding life quite difficult at the moment, as the current heightened geopolitical tensions—especially regarding Russia and Ukraine—are increasing uncertainties amid the still challenging conditions in many countries."
These heightened uncertainties have clearly impacted the economy—especially consumer confidence—and are presumably leading to some orders being delayed or even canceled, particularly large orders.
He said that it is becoming "increasingly likely" that the ECB will eventually have to initiate some kind of QE, "although we suspect that this will be limited."

"I am so grateful to God that he was returned to me. Here in Beslan, everyone is marked by it."
It remains in us..
Georgij is now an adult, but this horror is still within him.
"It's hard to accept that when something so unfair happens to you."
He is a boy, he likes sports, but he cannot participate because of his knee.
He has undergone multiple surgeries; he can walk but cannot engage in sports.
I would say that he has overcome the horror by 50%, but one can never completely overcome and forget that.

I have lost many people whom I knew well and who were dear to me.
"My son is with me, and that is the greatest gift that God could give me, but my heart weeps for the slain."
I know of families in which new children were born, but also of widows who never remarried.
It is hard to accept that life goes on, even if one doesn't want it to.
I will never forget how my heart leaped inside me when I saw him in the hospital.
"And now I see what is happening in the world—wars in other regions..."
What are these people fighting for?
Why do they kill each other?
"The war is now very close to our country, and I can hardly believe it."
"We used to be a friendly country; how is it possible that we are now fighting?"
People and children are suffering; I am sure that many children have already been killed in Ukraine and many more will be killed.
